bug.author: harshp8l
bug.summary: PyTorch with CUDA 11 Support yields to DGL cudaErrorCudartUnloading Error
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h2>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
Building dgl from source upon a CUDA 11 container with cuda 11 compatible pytorch - yields with error: <denchmark-code>dgl._ffi.base.DGLError: [10:15:47] /dgl/src/array/cuda/utils.cu:19: Check failed: e == cudaSuccess || e == cudaErrorCudartUnloading </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>To Reproduce</denchmark-h>
Build cuda11 image using dockerfile mentioned in this PR: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/aws/deep-learning-containers/pull/639>aws/deep-learning-containers#639</denchmark-link>
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
Clone DGL repo and checkout branch to version 0.5.2. Follow steps to build DGL from source Run test:
<denchmark-code>cd /dgl/examples/pytorch/gcn python ./train.py --dataset cora --gpu 0 </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-h:h2>Environment</denchmark-h>
DGL Version (e.g., 1.0): Backend Library & Version (e.g., PyTorch 0.4.1, MXNet/Gluon 1.3): OS (e.g., Linux): How you installed DGL (conda, pip, source): Build command you used (if compiling from source): Python version: CUDA/cuDNN version (if applicable): GPU models and configuration (e.g. V100): Any other relevant information:
<denchmark-h:h2>Additional context</denchmark-h>
CUDA Runtime and Driver Versions are correct and compatible since running ./deviceQuery results in: <denchmark-code>deviceQuery, CUDA Driver = CUDART, CUDA Driver Version = 11.0, CUDA Runtime Version = 11.0, NumDevs = 8 Result = PASS </denchmark-code>
PyTorch was binary created with CUDA 11 compatibility; using the PyTorch nightly binaries also yields with the same issue mentioned above: <denchmark-code>>>> import torch >>> torch.cuda.is_available() True >>> torch.version.cuda '11.0' >>> torch.cuda.get_arch_list() ['sm_37', 'sm_50', 'sm_60', 'sm_70', 'sm_75', 'sm_80'] </denchmark-code>
